1096043098591907840.text:
Inspired by the new JPM stablecoin, here is a short thread on 
- how Bitcoin achieves trust
- trusted middlemen
- and Bitcoin's true value

(Thread)

1096058106704998402.text:
Looks like "Wrapped Bitcoin" (WBTC), the bitcoin stablecoin that lives on Ethereum, isn't exactly off to a hot start. Since the launch, no more WBTC has been issued. Supply still sitting at ~70 BTC. 

Source:https://www.wbtc.network/dashboard/order-book …

1096043110763761664.text:
Your takeaways:
- Bitcoin rebuilds trust every block
- It needs to be expensive by design
- Trusted middlemen are amazing assets 
- Bitcoin is valuable where trust should be competitive, but isn't

1096043109283233794.text:
As a result, Bitcoin's true value lies in making trust competitive. 

It's a protocol for hosting trust tournaments, and hence building trust from scratch between total strangers.

1096043107857166337.text:
And that's fine because there are enough situations where middlemen cannot be trusted by definition. Why? Lack of competition.

The production of money is the prime example here. It's much harder for the market to punish a monopolist than a producer in a competitive market.

1096043106800152576.text: Tying it back together, if two parties already have a middleman they trust, then in practice they will always be better off using him instead of Bitcoin.

1096043105701253120.text:
Now if the king had candidates that he already trusts (for example his family), there would be no need for a costly tournament. 

The tournament is only for situations where trust has to be built from scratch every time.

1096043104652742656.text:
The strength of the trust is directly linked to the reward. 

This is why Bitcoin *needs* to be costly to use. (And it is also why some people are afraid Bitcoin becomes untrustworthy when rewards become smaller and smaller).

1096043103633444864.text:
The tournament process ensures that the winner has a high degree of integrity. 

But with every tournament, people only sign up if there is a sufficient reward waiting for the winner.

1096043102626869250.text:
Every block, Bitcoin hosts a tournament for your trust. 

For comparison, a king hosts a series of tournaments to find new members for his king's guard. New recruits are more likely to be skilled and trustworthy if they had to endure personal hardship to get the position.

1096043101561503744.text:
This is what Bitcoin solves: Lack of competition between middlemen. You're still trusting middlemen, but Bitcoin makes the middlemen prove first that they can be trusted. 

They do that by spending money before they can make money, which binds their honesty to their profit motive

1096043100584185861.text:
Trusted middlemen are extremely valuable. 

They only become problematic if there is no cost for misbehavior - for example, because there is no competition that keeps them in check.

1096043099585941504.text: Bitcoin will hardly be able to compete at transfers between people who trust each other or can have a trusted middleman. Why?

1096030942085427200.text:
This reminds me of free banking, only instead of gold the banks peg their currencies to fiat. 

Now it would be great if banks had a wider design space for their money, for example, reserve requirements, collateral types and much more.https://twitter.com/zhusu/status/1096023693992505344 …

Would be cool if a full node was more of a Bitcoin dashboard. 

A place to check all vital signals of the network, monitor last blocks, current mempool etc.

Turn it into a tool that builds trust and experience with Bitcoin.https://twitter.com/LukeDashjr/status/1095696536405712896 …

1095707496176599041.text:
Governance-by-democracy is terrible for blockchains. 

We need democracy to organize society where governance-by-exit is impossible. 

Exit solves the problems of democracy, yet we have tons of people in crypto who "rediscover" democracy to "solve" exit.

1095696010779787264.text:
Why on-chain governance is awful, Exhibit 159:

Based on this poll, even many bitcoiners would destroy the mining hardware of others if they got to replace it with mining hardware that they already own (their stake).pic.twitter.com/WLOcDCvndY

1095501917311197187.text: If governments stop providing society with cash, where will the people turn to make transactions that retain a basic level of privacy? What money do they hold when bank accounts no longer pay interest, but incur a tax in the form of negative interest?https://uncommoncore.co/bitcoin-is-a-hedge-against-the-cashless-society/ …

1095685069484814336.text:
The takeaways:
- future life expectancy of money and other Lindy goods goes up over time, not down
- the USD might well have another 50-100 years ahead of it
- new money competes on survival, not features
- so appreciate Bitcoin's defensive developer attitude

1095685068473974784.text:
All cryptos fight an uphill battle against established fiat currencies. And they compete less on features than you think and more on survival.

Most people will not start trusting Bitcoin's architecture. They trust their experience with it. And experience requires time.

1095685067408580609.text: Imagine for a moment what happens if Bitcoin died tomorrow after 10 years. It doesn't just reset the Lindy timer for all cryptocurrencies to zero. It sets it far below zero.

1095685066364280832.text:
If you adopt the survival-is-everything model for money, I promise you will start appreciating more the careful developer attitude behind Bitcoin. 

100% improvements in efficiency might not be worth it if there is a 5% chance that it kills you in the process.

1095685065194045440.text:
The most important thing Bitcoin has to do to become recognized as money is

survive. 

Would you trust a money to store your wealth for 10 years if it hasn't already proven to store someone else's wealth for 10 years?

1095685063960862722.text:
As a result, we can easily tell that a 50-year-old currency has a longer life expectancy than a newborn currency. After 50 years, it could have a new life expectancy of 100 years or more!

What does it all mean for Bitcoin?

1095685062916481026.text: A currency that is still going strong after 50 years tends to be widely recognized, distributed and integrated into our societies. In fact, it offers far more benefits than a new currency - which is why the network effects of money are so hard to break.

1095685061935017985.text: While increasing mortality applies to all biological or mechanical things, decreasing mortality tends to apply to the non-physical: ideas, technologies, institutions, religions, networks... the categories are overlapping but money falls squarely into several of them.

1095685060643180545.text: "The Lindy effect is a concept that the future life expectancy of some non-perishable things like a technology or an idea is proportional to their current age, so that every additional period of survival implies a longer remaining life expectancy." (N. Taleb)

1095685059556839424.text: Life expectancy decreasing proportionally to age applies to almost all living organisms, so it's an easy heuristic to over-apply. And indeed, some things are different. Enter the Lindy effect.

1095685058571177985.text: As humans, our life expectancy decreases the older we get because we are physically "running out of time". A German newborn has on average 90 years ahead of her. But on her 90th birthday, her new life expectancy is only 5 more years.

1094955528197951488.text: Changing their financial security model so they no longer benefit from liquidations would go a long way to shut down these criticisms.

1094954690897416193.text:
PS: No matter how you turn it, traditional exchanges don't make money when customers get liquidated. BitMEX does. 

This crass misalignment of incentives births all kinds of other speculation: Does BM weaponize server problems? Does it trade against their customers?

1094950357543895040.text: 3) The fund is segmented per contract, but the segments are not rolled over to the next quarter. How much money is reversed for each contract? What happens to the money when a contract expires?

1094950356583362560.text: 2) What do you plan on doing with any excess capital?

1094950355341848576.text:
Here are some more questions I would like to see answered:

1) At what size would you start calling the fund overcapitalized? Any plans on capping the fund and changing the model once that size is reached?

1094950354347876352.text: In summary, the post explains well why a high-leverage exchange *needs* some kind of safeguards, and if possible multiple layers of them. It gives no satisfying answers to why the BitMEX model of an internal "losers-pay-for-losers" fund is superior to existing models.

1094950353337044992.text: ADL means winners pay for the losers, but it also guarantees that customers will never pay more than is needed. The insurance fund means losers pay for losers, but makes them, in theory, overpay up 10x or more for the same security. The difference goes to BitMEX as profits.

1094950352208711680.text: So the fund is arguably too big, but that's not my main concern. It is that BitMEX itself owns the fund and not an external insurer or industry consortium. If they see the fund as what it is, an asset on their balance sheet, they are incentivized to grow it as much as possible.

1094950351223091201.text:
"Given the volatility [in the crypto space], it’s not impossible that the fund is drained down to zero again." 

I see that as increasingly unlikely, especially considering that since the last considerable loss (in April 2018), the fund has grown from 4.8k to 21k BTC.

1094950350216482816.text:
Better examples can be found in 2018:
16.1.2018, the fund lost 132 BTC (5% of total)
12.4.2018, the fund lost 641 BTC (13% of total)
18.7.2018, the fund lost 103 BTC (1% of total)
22.8.2018, the fund lost 155 BTC (1% of total)

1094950349050470401.text: So are BitMEX customers overinsured? The post gives a counterexample: In March 2017, the day the Winklevoss ETF was rejected, Bitcoin's price dropped 30% and depleted the insurance fund, causing ADL to happen. What it doesn't mention: The fund had only 66 BTC in it.

1094950347867672576.text: The insurance provided by the CME does explicitly NOT live on their own balance sheet. This is my big problem with the BitMEX insurance fund. CME has no incentive to overinsure their customers because they don't get to pocket excess money that is never paid out.

1094950346869432322.text:
That difference in itself is totally fine, as the CME is a KYC exchange and also has more of an institutional audience. Losses can, in theory, be recouped via the legal system, which is hardly possible on a non-KYC exchange like BitMEX. 

However...

1094950345808195585.text: First, they compared the size of the fund to safeguards employed by traditional exchanges like the CME. The sum of CME's insurance is around 29% of BitMEX's insurance relative to their respective annual notional trading volumes.

1094950344654770176.text:
Is BitMEX giving some much-needed transparency about their insurance fund? 

Threadhttps://twitter.com/BitMEXResearch/status/1094894482074542080 …

1082982456029036544.text: This explains why we rarely see any panic selling after 51% attacks, to date. The end users are affected neither financially (the exchange takes the hit), nor ideologically (users who value a project for their immutability don't store their money on exchanges).

1082980619863367680.text: To lose money from the most common 51% attacks, you either need to be an exchange or have money on an exchange that is hit so hard that you are affected as collateral.

1082980618730909696.text: Exchanges are the primary victim of 51% attacks. Exchanges don't list cryptocurrencies for their immutability, but to make money and apparently, the R/R pays off for them. It's *extremely* hard for a 51% attacker to target users who actually value immutability.https://twitter.com/hosseeb/status/1082815550193954817 …
